conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine when objects A and B are farthest apart.
The graph shows the velocity of objects A and B over time; the area under each curve represents displacement.
At t = 0, both objects start from the same location.
At t = t1, object A has a higher velocity than object B.
At t = t2, object A's velocity decreases to zero, while object B's velocity is still positive.
At t = t3, object A's velocity becomes negative, indicating it is moving in the opposite direction.
At t = t4, object B's velocity decreases to zero.
The displacement of each object at any time t is the area under the respective velocity-time curve up to that time.
To find when the objects are farthest apart, compare the areas under the curves for both objects.
From t = 0 to t = t2, object A is moving forward and then stops, while object B continues moving forward.
From t = t2 to t = t3, object A starts moving backward, while object B continues moving forward.
The maximum separation occurs when the difference in the areas under the curves is the greatest.
The maximum separation occurs at t = t3, where the area under object B's curve is the largest compared to the area under object A's curve.
The two objects are farthest apart at t = t3.
